author: msftrncs
body:
# Steps to reproduce

attempt to use powershell to call pwsh, using tab completion, to form a `-FILE` parameter to a UNC path.  Example resulting command:
```powershell
pwsh -file 'Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\FileSystem::\\rk-vs-fs1\engineering\programming\PowerShell\PwshIFMResXTools\IFM MPC RESX Reducer.ps1'
```
(the provider notation was provided by tab completion.  I started with just `\\rk-vs-fs1\engineering`)

# Expected behavior

I expect a new instance of PowerShell Core to run the script.

# Actual behavior

The new instance provides an error:

`The argument 'Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\FileSystem::\\rk-vs-fs1\engineering\programming\PowerShell\PwshIFMResXTools\IFM MPC RESX Reducer.ps1' is not recognized as the name of a script file. Check the spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.`

# Environment data

```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.2.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    6.2.0
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.17763
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```
# References

Reference #9395, I thought this worked on PowerShell Core, but the error message is just different.

If I run the following, it works:
```PowerShell
pwsh -file '\\rk-vs-fs1\engineering\programming\PowerShell\PwshIFMResXTools\IFM MPC RESX Reducer.ps1'
# or
& 'Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\FileSystem::\\rk-vs-fs1\engineering\programming\PowerShell\PwshIFMResXTools\IFM MPC RESX Reducer.ps1'
```
title: -FILE parameter doesn't accept provider path notation
